subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Clean Heavy-Duty Vehicles
sectionText:
SEC. 42101. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO CLEAN HEAVY-DUTY 
              VEHICLES.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 132 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7432) is 
repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 132 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7432) (as 
in effect on the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is 
rescinded.
summary: Eliminates the Inflation Reduction Act’s $1 billion rebate/grant program that was about to fund the purchase of zero-emission school buses, garbage trucks, and port-drayage rigs and to cover related charging or hydrogen infrastructure.  All unobligated funds are clawed back.
impact: Eliminates a still-growing $1 billion program that focused on the dirtiest vehicles on U.S. roads. Class 6–8 trucks log only about 6 % of all vehicle-miles but pump out more than 55 % of on-road NOx and PM-2.5. EPA modeling showed that, once the first fleet tranche rolled out, the incentive would avert roughly 700 000 tons of CO₂, 4 000 tons of NOx, and 200 tons of PM each year. Demand was strong: the 2024 inaugural round drew pre-applications from more than 2 100 school districts, transit agencies, and drayage operators—five times the money on offer. Without the grant, those entities must pivot to much smaller, oversubscribed pots (DERA, BIL Clean School Bus) or settle for new diesel rigs. Manufacturers such as Blue Bird, Lion Electric, and Nikola had already expanded lines and supply deals on the assumption of stable federal orders through 2031, so the abrupt repeal guts their backlogs, chills new battery-plant plans, and stalls the volume-driven price declines the sector needs.

Fiscal gains are negligible next to the lost health and climate benefits. Scrapping the unobligated balance shaves barely 0.02 % from ten-year discretionary spending, yet the EPA had pegged avoided asthma attacks and hospital stays at up to $6 billion in savings over the same window. The agency must now unwind open solicitations and pull back tentative awards; buyers that have already placed orders may sue for reliance damages. Section 132 of the Inflation Reduction Act also earmarked at least 40 % of funds for disadvantaged communities, so cancellation risks widening pollution gaps along urban freight corridors. Bottom line: the move slows heavy-duty electrification, shifts costs back to local governments, and clouds the business case for U.S. e-truck manufacturing while offering only token deficit relief.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Grants to Reduce Air Pollution at Ports
sectionText:
SEC. 42102. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO GRANTS TO REDUCE AIR 
              POLLUTION AT PORTS.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 133 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7433) is 
repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 133 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7433) (as 
in effect on the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is 
rescinded.
summary: Eliminates Clean Air Act §133 and rescinds the remaining balance for the IRA Ports Pollution Reduction Grant Program intended for shore-power, cargo-handling electrification, and truck transition projects at maritime and inland ports.
impact: Port authorities lose a dedicated federal source for electrifying equipment and installing shore-side power, potentially prolonging diesel emissions in surrounding communities.  Almost the entire possible $3 billion in grants were were already awarded, leaving only $600,000 in savings assuming the EPA does not attempt to shirk existing obligations.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund
sectionText:
SEC. 42103. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO GREENHOUSE GAS REDUCTION 
              FUND.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 134 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7434) is 
repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 134 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7434) (as 
in effect on the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is 
rescinded.
summary: Repeals Clean Air Act §134 and rescinds the unobligated balance of the $27 billion Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund (GGRF) that capitalizes EPA’s new national clean-energy financing network, including the Solar for All and Clean Communities Accelerator competitions.
impact: Halts remaining awards that would have flowed to green banks and CDFIs for low-income solar, building retrofits, and EV charging.  Though the entire balance has already been obligated, the EPA during the Trump presidency has been battling to avoid paying for these projects.  Existing announced grantees could face claw-backs or reduced disbursements.  Financial-innovation advocates warn the repeal removes a leverage point designed to crowd-in private capital for emissions reductions.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Diesel Emissions Reductions
sectionText:
SEC. 42104. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO DIESEL EMISSIONS 
              REDUCTIONS.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60104 of Public Law 117-169 is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60104 of Public Law 117-169 (as in effect on 
the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is rescinded.
summary: Repeals IRA §60104 and rescinds any unobligated Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) supplemental funding that had boosted grants and rebates for older diesel engine replacements in school buses, locomotives, and construction equipment.
impact: Shrinks EPA’s DERA grant pool by roughly $60 million, reducing near-term particulate-matter and NOx reduction projects.  Rural school districts and small trucking firms lose an expanded avenue for lower-emission equipment financing.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Funding to Address Air Pollution
sectionText:
SEC. 42105. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO FUNDING TO ADDRESS AIR 
              POLLUTION.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60105 of Public Law 117-169 is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60105 of Public Law 117-169 (as in effect on 
the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is rescinded.
summary: Repeals IRA §60105 and rescinds the unobligated balance of $250 million that EPA was using for fenceline air-monitor deployment, community pollution monitoring, and environmental-justice data integration.
impact:
•  Cancels or reduces hundreds of community-driven air-sensor grants, hampering localized exposure tracking.  
•  EJ groups argue it diminishes transparency; fiscal hawks view it as duplicative of existing monitoring networks.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Funding to Address Air Pollution at Schools
sectionText:
SEC. 42106. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO FUNDING TO ADDRESS AIR 
              POLLUTION AT SCHOOLS.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60106 of Public Law 117-169 is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60106 of Public Law 117-169 (as in effect on 
the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is rescinded.
summary: Rescinds IRA §60106 and its remaining $50 million for grants that install air-filtration systems, monitoring, and zero-emission vehicle infrastructure at public schools in disadvantaged areas.
impact:
•  Delays HVAC upgrades and on-site charging projects aimed at reducing students’ exposure to diesel exhaust and wildfire smoke.  
•  Leaves many districts to rely solely on limited state facilities budgets.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Low-Emissions Electricity Program
sectionText:
SEC. 42107. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO LOW EMISSIONS ELECTRICITY 
              PROGRAM.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 135 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7435) is 
repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 135 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7435) (as 
in effect on the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is 
rescinded.
summary: Repeals Clean Air Act §135 and rescinds unobligated IRA funding that would have supported consumer education, industry technical assistance, and methane-emissions measurement for low-emission electricity generation.
impact:
•  Curtails EPA outreach intended to help utilities and cooperatives adopt best-available low-carbon practices.  
•  Could slow voluntary methane-leak detection pilots in power-sector supply chains.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Funding for Section 211(o) of the Clean Air Act
sectionText:
SEC. 42108. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO FUNDING FOR SECTION 
              211(O) OF THE CLEAN AIR ACT.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60108 of Public Law 117-169 is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60108 of Public Law 117-169 (as in effect on 
the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is rescinded.
summary: Eliminates IRA §60108 funding that bolstered EPA staffing and data systems for administering the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) under CAA §211(o).
impact:
•  May slow EPA rulemaking timelines for annual RFS volume obligations and small-refinery petitions.  
•  Biofuel producers fear added market uncertainty; opponents of the RFS see cost savings.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Funding for Implementation of the American Innovation and Manufacturing Act
sectionText:
SEC. 42109. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO FUNDING FOR 
              IMPLEMENTATION OF THE AMERICAN INNOVATION AND 
              MANUFACTURING ACT.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60109 of Public Law 117-169 is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60109 of Public Law 117-169 (as in effect on 
the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is rescinded.
summary: Repeals IRA §60109 and pulls back unobligated dollars for EPA’s implementation of the AIM Act phase-down of HFC refrigerants, including rule enforcement and technology transitions.
impact:
•  Could undercut U.S. compliance with the Kigali Amendment schedule, risking supply disruptions for HVAC/R industries.  
•  Manufacturers warn of slower refrigerant-tracking system upgrades.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Funding for Enforcement Technology and Public Information
sectionText:
SEC. 42110. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO FUNDING FOR ENFORCEMENT 
              TECHNOLOGY AND PUBLIC INFORMATION.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60110 of Public Law 117-169 is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60110 of Public Law 117-169 (as in effect on 
the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is rescinded.
summary: Rescinds IRA §60110, removing funds that expanded EPA’s digital permitting dashboards, emissions-reporting portals, and remote-sensing enforcement tools.
impact: •  May slow modernization of EPA compliance systems, increasing reporting burdens on industry and hampering public transparency.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Greenhouse Gas Corporate Reporting
sectionText:
SEC. 42111. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO GREENHOUSE GAS CORPORATE 
              REPORTING.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60111 of Public Law 117-169 is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60111 of Public Law 117-169 (as in effect on 
the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is rescinded.
summary: Repeals IRA §60111 funding that would have supported EPA upgrades to the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program and development of corporate climate-risk disclosure tools.
impact: •  Limits EPA’s ability to integrate facility-level GHG data with SEC-style corporate inventories, potentially complicating future disclosure mandates.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Environmental Product Declaration Assistance
sectionText:
SEC. 42112. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO ENVIRONMENTAL PRODUCT 
              DECLARATION ASSISTANCE.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60112 of Public Law 117-169 (42 U.S.C. 4321 
note) is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60112 of Public Law 117-169 (42 U.S.C. 4321 
note) (as in effect on the day before the date of enactment of this 
Act) is rescinded.
summary: Repeals IRA §60112 and rescinds funds designated for EPA technical assistance and grants that help construction-material manufacturers create Environmental Product Declarations (EPDs) showing life-cycle carbon data.
impact:
•  Hampers Buy-Clean initiatives that rely on transparent embodied-carbon data for steel, cement, and asphalt.  
•  Industry consortia say reduced EPD uptake could disadvantage U.S. exporters in EU carbon-border regimes.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal of Funding for Methane Emissions and Waste Reduction Incentive Program for Petroleum and Natural Gas Systems
sectionText:
SEC. 42113. REPEAL OF FUNDING FOR METHANE EMISSIONS AND WASTE REDUCTION 
              INCENTIVE PROGRAM FOR PETROLEUM AND NATURAL GAS SYSTEMS.

    (a) Repeal and Rescission.--Subsections (a) and (b) of section 136 
of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7436) are repealed and the unobligated 
balances of amounts made available under those subsections (as in 
effect on the day before the date of enactment of this Act) are 
rescinded.
    (b) Conforming Amendments.--Section 136 of the Clean Air Act (42 
U.S.C. 7436) is amended--
            (1) by redesignating subsections (c) through (i) as 
        subsections (a) through (g), respectively;
            (2) by striking ``subsection (c)'' each place it appears 
        and inserting ``subsection (a)'';
            (3) by striking ``subsection (d)'' each place it appears 
        and inserting ``subsection (b)'';
            (4) by striking ``subsection (f)'' each place it appears 
        and inserting ``subsection (d)'';
            (5) in subsection (e) (as so redesignated), by striking 
        ``calendar year 2024'' and inserting ``calendar year 2034''; 
        and
            (6) in subsection (f) (as so redesignated)--
                    (A) by striking ``subsections (e) and (f)'' and 
                inserting ``subsections (c) and (d)''; and
                    (B) by striking ``including data collected pursuant 
                to subsection (a)(4),''.
summary: Repeals and rescinds subsections (a) and (b) of CAA §136, which provided $850 million for methane-monitoring grants to oil-and-gas facilities and tribal regulators.  Retains—but renumbers—the methane waste-emissions fee that begins in 2024, extending its data-collection authority through 2034.
impact:
•  Removes incentives that would have helped smaller producers install leak-detection and flare-capture technology before the emissions fee ramps up.  
•  Industry voices argue grant removal increases compliance costs; environmental groups warn of higher methane leakage.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Greenhouse Gas Air Pollution Plans and Implementation Grants
sectionText:
SEC. 42114. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO GREENHOUSE GAS AIR 
              POLLUTION PLANS AND IMPLEMENTATION GRANTS.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 137 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7437) is 
repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 137 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7437) (as 
in effect on the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is 
rescinded.
summary: Repeals CAA §137 and rescinds remaining funds for EPA’s Climate Pollution Reduction Grants, which were providing planning- and implementation-grants to states, tribes, and metro areas for GHG-reduction strategies.
impact:
•  Terminates billions in pending awards for electric-bus fleets, building-efficiency upgrades, and industrial decarbonization plans crafted by states in 2023 planning grants.  
•  May leave local governments without resources to execute plans already developed.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to EPA Efficient, Accurate, and Timely Reviews
sectionText:
SEC. 42115. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION 
              AGENCY EFFICIENT, ACCURATE, AND TIMELY REVIEWS.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60115 of Public Law 117-169 is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60115 of Public Law 117-169 (as in effect on 
the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is rescinded.
summary: Rescinds IRA §60115 funding that enhanced EPA staffing and IT systems for faster environmental-review permitting (e.g., NEPA, FIFRA, TSCA).
impact:
•  Could slow permit processing for energy and infrastructure projects—including fossil and renewables—that rely on EPA technical reviews.  
•  Undermines bipartisan permitting-reform goals.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Low-Embodied Carbon Labeling for Construction Materials
sectionText:
SEC. 42116. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO LOW-EMBODIED CARBON 
              LABELING FOR CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 60116 of Public Law 117-169 (42 U.S.C. 4321 
note) is repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 60116 of Public Law 117-169 (42 U.S.C. 4321 
note) (as in effect on the day before the date of enactment of this 
Act) is rescinded.
summary: Repeals IRA §60116 and rescinds funds for developing a federal low-carbon labeling system for construction materials in coordination with GSA and FHWA.
impact:
•  Removes federal push for harmonized embodied-carbon standards, complicating state procurement efforts and private EPD schemes.  
•  Construction-material suppliers lose a future federal market signal for low-carbon products.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal and Rescission Relating to Environmental and Climate Justice Block Grants
sectionText:
SEC. 42117. REPEAL AND RESCISSION RELATING TO ENVIRONMENTAL AND CLIMATE 
              JUSTICE BLOCK GRANTS.

    (a) Repeal.--Section 138 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7438) is 
repealed.
    (b) Rescission.--The unobligated balance of any amounts made 
available under section 138 of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7438) (as 
in effect on the day before the date of enactment of this Act) is 
rescinded.
summary: Repeals CAA §138 and rescinds unobligated funds for EPA’s $3 billion Environmental and Climate Justice Block Grant program targeted to community-based organizations in overburdened neighborhoods.
impact:
•  Community groups lose grants for lead-abatement, urban greening, air-sensor networks, and climate-resilient infrastructure.  
•  Could widen disparities in areas lacking state or philanthropic alternatives.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal of EPA Rules Relating to Greenhouse Gas and Multi-Pollutant Emissions Standards
sectionText:
SEC. 42201. REPEAL OF EPA RULES RELATING TO GREENHOUSE GAS AND MULTI-
              POLLUTANT EMISSIONS STANDARDS.

    The final rules issued by the Environmental Protection Agency 
relating to ``Revised 2023 and Later Model Year Light-Duty Vehicle 
Greenhouse Gas Emissions Standards'' (86 Fed. Reg. 74434 (December 30, 
2021)) and ``Multi-Pollutant Emissions Standards for Model Years 2027 
and Later Light-Duty and Medium-Duty Vehicles'' (89 Fed. Reg. 27842 
(April 18, 2024)) shall have no force or effect.
summary: Voids EPA’s December 2021 light-duty vehicle GHG rule for model years 2023-26 and the April 2024 multi-pollutant standards for MY 2027+ passenger cars and light/medium trucks.
impact:
•  Reverts federal tailpipe GHG limits to the weaker 2020 SAFE standards unless/until EPA restarts rulemaking.  
•  Complicates automakers’ product-planning and California’s waiver alignment.  
•  May increase cumulative U.S. oil demand and greenhouse-gas emissions through 2035.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Repeal of NHTSA Rules Relating to CAFE Standards
sectionText:
SEC. 42301. REPEAL OF NHTSA RULES RELATING TO CAFE STANDARDS.

    The final rules issued by the National Highway Traffic Safety 
Administration relating to ``Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards 
for Model Years 2024-2026 Passenger Cars and Light Trucks'' (87 Fed. 
Reg. 25710 (May 2, 2022)) and ``Corporate Average Fuel Economy 
Standards for Passenger Cars and Light Trucks for Model Years 2027 and 
Beyond and Fuel Efficiency Standards for Heavy-Duty Pickup Trucks and 
Vans for Model Years 2030 and Beyond'' (89 Fed. Reg. 52540 (June 24, 
2024)) shall have no force or effect.
summary: Voids NHTSA’s May 2022 CAFE standards for MY 2024-26 light-duty vehicles and June 2024 rule proposing stricter CAFE targets for MY 2027+ cars, light trucks, and heavy-duty pickups/vans.
impact:
•  Leaves current CAFE target at MY 2021 levels (40 mpg fleet average) until new rulemaking, potentially raising fuel consumption and greenhouse-gas emissions.  
•  Undermines automaker planning synchrony with EPA emissions rules; may prompt litigation from states and environmental groups.
